claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling in tumors.

evidence.quote: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |

claims.caveat: This report summarizes normalized scores but does not provide full experimental details or variability; mechanistic readouts were not uniformly strongest across all settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens antigen processing/presentation and expands the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: 3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
| Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |

claims.caveat: The summary provides fractions of proteins represented but does not specify which tumor models or technical parameters drove the changes, limiting generalizability.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination increases PD-L1 pathway activity, supporting combination with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: 4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
| PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |

claims.caveat: Increased PD-L1 expression can reflect inflammatory signaling and does not by itself prove improved clinical benefit without direct outcome data in controlled settings.

claims.claim: The combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

evidence.quote: 5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

claims.caveat: The human evidence is retrospective and non-randomized with heterogeneous timing and tumor types, so association cannot establish causality.

claims.claim: Type I interferon signaling is required for the sensitization effect, and non-mRNA lipid particle controls do not reproduce it.

evidence.quote: - Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
- Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: These are summarized control statements without effect sizes; the report does not quantify the degree of elimination or whether alternative pathways contribute.
